Market Volatility (VIX) Signal

VIX market volatility signal: tracking investor fear and uncertainty.

As of 2026-01-10

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Market Volatility Signal (1) has transitioned from CALM to NORMAL, with the VIX closing at 15.45 and a composite z-score of 0.005 on 2026-01-08. This indicates a slight increase in perceived market risk from previously subdued levels.
  • Conviction Band: Medium | Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence | Internal Conflict Flag: No

Key Dynamics:

  • The current VIX level (15.45) is below 16, but the Market Volatility Signal's robust z-score (0.005) has moved just above the 0 threshold. This marginal shift from a negative to a positive z-score is the primary driver for the transition to a NORMAL regime (1).
  • Momentum indicators for the VIX, such as 5-day and 20-day changes, contribute to the composite score's shift.
  • Conditional Invalidation: The signal would reverse to CALM if the composite z-score consistently fell back below 0 while the VIX remained under 16.

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant: Market volatility remains in a NORMAL regime, fluctuating around current levels, supported by the composite z-score staying within the [0, +0.5) range.
  • Upside secondary: A sharp, unexpected market downturn or macro event could cause the VIX to spike above 20, pushing the signal into an ELEVATED or STRESSED regime.
  • Downside residual: Sustained market stability and confidence could lead to the composite z-score dropping below 0, returning the signal to a CALM regime.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Tactical (weeks). The VIX is explicitly a short-horizon risk gauge.
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: Medium. This signal offers a crucial, real-time pulse on market sentiment, valuable for tactical adjustments and risk assessment within a broader composite.

Macro Relevance:

  • Macro dimension informed: Sentiment, Risk.
  • Cycle position: A NORMAL VIX regime typically aligns with mid-cycle expansion, where acute market stress is absent but underlying risks are not fully dismissed.
  • Typical interaction with other macro signals: Rising VIX with tightening liquidity (2) or widening credit spreads (3) reinforces a risk-off macro stance (1).

Data & References:

  • CBOE Volatility Index (VIXCLS) data as of 2026-01-08. The latest VIX value of 15.45 and the MVS_z of 0.005 were most influential for the current state.
  • Additional public datasets that would improve depth or reliability: Realized equity volatility (e.g., S&P 500 historical volatility) and Equity futures positioning (e.g., E-mini S&P 500 CoT data).
